pymerkle.nodes module¶

Provides the base class for the Merkle-Tree’s nodes and an inheriting class for its leaves

class pymerkle.nodes.leaf(record, hash_function)[source]¶

Bases: pymerkle.nodes.node

Class for the leafs of Merkle-Tree (parentless nodes). Inherits from the node class

Parameters:
  • record (str or bytes or bytearray) – the record to be encrypted within the leaf
  • hash_function (method) – hash function to be used for encryption (only once). Should be the .hash attribute of the containing Merkle-Tree
class pymerkle.nodes.node(hash_function, record=None, left=None, right=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Base class for the nodes of a Merkle-Tree

Parameters:
  • record (str or bytes or bytearray) – [optional] the record to be encrypted within the node. If provided, then the node is considered to be a leaf
  • left (nodes.node) – [optional] the node’s left parent. If not provided, then the node is considered to be a leaf
  • right (nodes.node) – [optional] the node’s right parent. If not provided, then the node is considered to be a leaf
  • hash_function (method) – hash function to be used for encryption. Should be the .hash attribute of the containing Merkle-Tree
Variables:
  • left – (nodes.node) The node’s left parent. Defaults to None if the node is a leaf
  • right – (nodes.node) The node’s right parent. Defaults to None if the node is a leaf
  • child – (nodes.node) The node’s child parent. Defaults to None if the node is a root
  • hash – (str) The hash currently stored by the node (hex)
  • hash_function – (method) The hash function used by the node for encryption. For interior nodes it is equal to the .hash attribute of the containing Merkle-Tree. For leaf nodes it is None (no hash re-calculation case)
JSONstring()[source]¶

Returns a nicely stringified version of the node’s JSON serialized form

Note

The output of this function is to be passed in the print() function

Return type:str
descendant(degree)[source]¶

Detects and returns the node that is degree steps upwards within the containing Merkle-Tree.

Note

Descendant of degree 0 is the node itself, descendant of degree 1 is the node’s child, etc.

Parameters:degree (int) – depth of descendancy. Must be non-negative
Returns:the descendant corresdponding to the requested depth
Return type:nodes.node

Note

Returns None if the requested depth of dependancy exceeds possibilities

isLeftParent()[source]¶

Checks if the node is a left parent.

Returns:True iff the node is the .left attribute of some other node inside the containing Merkle-Tree
Return type:bool
isRightParent()[source]¶

Checks if the node is a right parent.

Returns:True iff the node is the .right attribute of some other node inside the containing Merkle-Tree
Return type:bool
recalculate_hash()[source]¶

Recalculates the node’s hash under account of its parents’ new hashes

This method is to be invoked for all non-leaf nodes of the Merkle-Tree’s rightmost branch every time a new leaf is appended into the tree.

Warning

Only for interior nodes (i.e., with two parents); fails in case of leaf nodes

serialize()[source]¶

Returns a JSON structure with the node’s attributes as key-value pairs

Return type:dict

Note

The .child attribute is excluded in order for circular reference error to be avoided

class pymerkle.nodes.nodeEncoder(*, skipkeys=False, ensure_ascii=True, check_circular=True, allow_nan=True, sort_keys=False, indent=None, separators=None, default=None)[source]¶

Bases: json.encoder.JSONEncoder

Used implicitely in the JSON serialization of nodes. Extends the built-in JSON encoder for data structures.

default(obj)[source]¶

Overrides the built-in method of JSON encoders according to the needs of this library.

Note

The .child attribute is excluded from JSON formatting of nodes in order for circular reference error to be avoided.
